Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Dionex Accelerated Solvent Extractor for Biogeochemistry, Toxicology, and Marine Science Research at Hawaii Pacific University
Award.AbstractNarration: This award funds the acquisition of a Dionex Accelerated Solvent Extraction (ASE) system to enhance faculty and student research opportunities and to improve teaching infrastructure at HPU. The ASE system will be used in a variety of active research projects funded by NSF and other agencies which require frequent use of ASE equipment for extraction of lipids, environmental contaminants, and natural metabolic products. The instrument will be used for a number of diverse projects including (a) carbon isotope fractionation in lipid biosynthesis by piezophilic bacteria isolated from the deeply buried Shimokita Coalbed (1498.48 and 2406.84 meter below the seafloor) in the northwest Pacific; (b) assessing historical changes in Kawai`nui marsh ecosystem; (c) measuring stress-induced hormones in wild dolphins as an indicator of negative environmental impacts on dolphin populations (d) the development of natural product chemical libraries; and (e) measuring organic contaminants in tissues of marine vertebrates. HPU is currently in transition from a predominantly undergraduate, non-Ph.D. granting teaching institution into a comprehensive university with a strong research program, and such state-of-the-art instrumentation will help facilitate this transition. Postdoctoral research associates and M.S. graduate and undergraduate students will be trained on the use of the instrument. Hawaii Pacific University (HPU) is a minority serving undergraduate research institution on the Island of Oahu in a state with few centers of higher learning in Hawaii compared with the continental United States. The HPU student population includes significant representation by local native Hawaiians as well as Pacific Islanders that come to Hawaii for a college education. Hence the funding of this instrumentation will have broad impacts on a diverse student population in research and education in fields such as Biology, Biochemistry, Marine Biology and Oceanography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

 

Title: MRI: Acquisition of a Dionex Accelerated Solvent Extractor for Biogeochemistry, Toxicology, and Marine Science Research at Hawaii Pacific University 

 

PI: Jiasong Fang

Co-PI’s: Dr. Kristi West; Dr. Brenda Jensen; Dr. David Horgen 

 

  1. A.    The Dionex Accelerated Solvent Extractor

The Dionex Accelerated Solvent Extractor (ASE) is widely used in the environmental, pharmaceutical, agricultural, and chemical industries as well as in academic research. Compared to the traditional solvent extractor, the Dionex ASE system is superior in extracting analytes (chemical or biochemical compounds) from different sample matrices (sediment, water, or biological samples). The instrument uses a combination of elevated temperature and pressure to increase the efficiency of the solvent extraction process. The significant advantages of the ASE system include:

 

(1)   Better extraction efficiency: due to decreased solvent viscosity, allowing better penetration of solvent molecules into the sample matrix, increased analyte solubility, and therefore increased extraction efficiency and decreased labor.

(2)   Reduced extraction time. For example, to extract lipids from research samples, we typically use the classical Bligh-Dye method. This method requires 24-hour extraction of the samples. Using the ASE system the extraction time can be reduced to 35–45 min for extracting phospholipids from bacterial and sediment samples.

(3)   Environmentally friendly. The instrument uses much less solvent in extraction. This is because of the increased penetration of solvent molecules into the sample matrix and enhanced solvent-analyte interaction, and higher extraction efficiency. The Dionex ASE saves 50–90% of extraction solvent compared to classical extractors, like the Soxhlet extractor.

 

  1. B.     Project outcomes

Acquisition of the ASE system allowed us to continue our existing projects in biogeochemistry, toxicology, and natural product chemistry, and develop new analytical methods for our research. One method developed was to use the ASE system to extract dipicolinic acid (DPA) from bacterial endospores in sediment samples of the deep marine subsurface biosphere. Endospores are metabolically inactive form of bacteria, and can remain viable for thousands and probably millions of years. Endospores are formed under unfavorable or extreme environmental conditions, including high temperature, high pressure, high radioactivity, etc. The deep marine subsurface biosphere is typically defined as that 1 m below the seafloor. Research on the deep biosphere has important implications for studying global carbon cycle, climate change, origin of life, and formation and distribution of mineral and biological resources. When studying the deep biosphere, the first pressing question is: what is out there in the deep subsurface? That is, we need to know what microorganisms are living in the deep biosphere. However, the DNA-/RNA-based modern molecular microbiological techniques cannot detect bacterial endospores in environmental samples. This is because endospores are impermeable and are not stained by fluorescence DNA dyes or by ribosomal RNA staining techniques. However, in every bacterial endospore, there exists a biochemical compound (or biomarker) in the core, dipicolinic acid (DPA). DPA is a universal and specific component of bacterial endospores, representing 5–15wt% of the dry spore. Therefore, DPA is a useful indicator and quantifier of bacterial endospores and permits to estimate the total spore numbers in the subsurface biosphere. For the same reason, the traditional solvent extraction method cannot be used for an efficient extraction of DPA from bacterial endospores. But by using the ASE system which employs high temperature and high pressure in extraction to break the spores (but does not destroy DPA), we can extract DPA from spore very efficiently. Then the identification and quantification of DPA is accomplished by using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS).

The instrument has been playing a critical role in developing new research projects and carrying out funded research projects. It also provided an opportunity to train graduate and undergraduate students. Students have been trained on the use of the instrument and on method development in traditional research areas (like extracting lipids, natural products, and environmental contaminants) and also in new research areas (extracting hormones from sea creatures and bacterial endospores from sediment of the deep biosphere). The ASE has also been used as teaching infrastructure to enhance integrating research and education at HPU by providing expanded research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.
